title: Nicholas P. Sweeney
text:
Nicholas P. Sweeney is the Sir Terry Leahy Fellow of Urban and Regional Economics at Alliance Manchester Business School.
His research examines the multi-dimensional drivers and effects of spatial inequality, and the role of place-based policy in ameliorating disparities both between and within regions. Underpinning his research is the use of contemporary data availability improvements to refine theoretical and empirical understanding of longstanding debates on economic, political and social matters.
The why of Nicholas’ holistic research comes from growing up in Liverpool, a region that has experienced significant economic decline and now evidences some of the lowest incomes, political engagement and health outcomes in England – the most spatially unequal developed country. The belief that evidenced-based, practical, applied research and policy lessons can help to improve livelihoods across the world motivates his work.







Institutions, decentralisation, and multi-level governance

Spatial inequalities and local economic development

Political (dis)engagement in declining places

Mobility, access to services, and health inequalities





Causal inference in applied microeconometrics (difference-in-differences, matching, instrumental variables)

Spatial analysis and geospatial data (GIS / QGIS workflows)

Reproducible research in R and Python




Nicholas joined the University of Manchester in 2025 from the University of Cambridge, after submitting his three solo-authored PhD entitled Devolution and Space in England: Empirical Essays on Economic Growth, Democratic Engagement and Health in under three years. All three papers were subsequently published in leading journals (Urban Studies, Political Geography, and Social Science & Medicine, respectively).
Nicholas also completed his Master’s and undergraduate studies at the University of Cambridge. He gained a Distinction in his Master’s degree and received the highest overall marks in his undergraduate cohort, as well as the award for best final-year dissertation.

title: Nicholas P. Sweeney
text:
Nicholas P. Sweeney is the Sir Terry Leahy Fellow of Urban and Regional Economics at Alliance Manchester Business School. His research examines the political and economic drivers of spatial inequality, with a particular focus on the role of institutions, multi-level governance, and place-based policy in England.
Nicholas joined the University of Manchester in 2025 from the University of Cambridge, after submitting his three solo authored papers PhD entitled ‘Devolution and Space in England: Empirical Essays on Economic Growth, Democratic Engagement and Health’ in under three years. All of these papers were subsequently published in leading journals (Urban Studies, Political Geography, Social Sciences & Medicine – respectively).
Nicholas also completed his Masters and Undergraduate studies at the University of Cambridge. Notable achievements include a Distinction in his Masters, with a high mark of 87% in Research Methods, and during his undergraduate where received the most marks in his cohort, and the award for best third-year dissertation.
